title: 108_hr2450
content: The Act is titled the "Human Space Flight Independent Investigation Commission Act of 2003" and defines key terms such as "incident," "NASA," "NASA Administrator," and "NTSB." It establishes a commission for the investigation. Establishment of an independent, nonpartisan Commission within the executive branch to investigate incidents involving the loss of space vehicles or crew members. The President must establish the Commission within 7 days of such an incident. The Commission established under this Act will consist of 15 members. The Chairman of the NTSB will be a member, and the President will appoint the remaining 14 members, including the Chairman and Vice Chairman. Four members will be selected by the President based on recommendations from Senate and House leaders. The Commission established under this Act will consist of 15 members, with the President selecting one candidate from each of the 4 lists for membership. No federal government officer or employee, except the NTSB Chairman, can serve on the Commission. Members cannot have a contractual relationship with NASA, and individuals with conflicts of interest with the NASA Administrator will not be appointed. The President will ensure diversity among Commission members. The Commission will consist of individuals with experience in human carrying spacecraft, investigative, and legal fields. The President will ensure diversity in the membership. All members must be appointed within 30 days of the incident, and the Commission will meet promptly to begin operations. Eight members will constitute a quorum, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission established under this Act will investigate incidents, determine causes, identify contributing factors, make recommendations for corrective actions, provide additional important findings or recommendations, and prepare a report for Congress, the President, and the public. The Commission established under this Act may hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and issue subpoenas to gather information for carrying out its duties. Subpoenas under this subsection can only be issued by the agreement of the Chairman and the Vice Chairman or by the affirmative vote of 8 members of the Commission. Subpoenas may be issued under the signature of the Chairman or any designated member and served by any designated person. Enforcement in cases of contumacy is specified. In cases of contumacy or failure to obey a subpoena, the United States district court can issue an order for the person to testify or produce evidence. Failure to comply may result in contempt of court. Additional enforcement measures are also available for witnesses who fail to comply. The Commission can certify witness failures to the US attorney for grand jury action under the same authority as specified statutes. Commission may also contract within provided limits. The Commission can enter into contracts within specified limits to fulfill its duties under the Act. It is authorized to obtain information directly from federal agencies for the purposes of the Act. The Commission, chaired by a subcommittee member designated by the majority, must handle information in accordance with laws and regulations. The General Services Administration provides administrative support to the Commission, and other federal agencies can also offer assistance. The Commission may receive services, funds, facilities, staff, and support from US agencies as authorized by law. A Commission established under this Act can use the US mails like other government departments. SEC. 7 of the Act requires a Commission to hold public meetings, release public reports, and conduct public hearings in a manner that protects sensitive information. SEC. 8 addresses the staff of the Commission. The Chairman, with consultation from the Vice Chairman, can appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain regulations, except for pay limits. NASA employees cannot be part of the Commission's staff. The executive director and personnel of a Commission established under this Act are federal employees under title 5, United States Code. Members of the Commission are not considered federal employees. Federal Government employees, excluding NASA employees, can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission established under this Act can procure consultant services from experts at rates not exceeding the daily rate of a level IV Executive Schedule position. Consultants must disclose any contracts or associations with NASA or its contractors. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of a Commission established under this Act may receive compensation at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing Commission duties. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. SEC. 10. Security clearances for Commission members and staff. Federal agencies must provide security clearances to Commission members and staff promptly. Access to classified information requires appropriate clearances. The Commission established by this Act can submit interim and final reports to the President, Congress, and the public. The final report must include findings, conclusions, recommendations, and minority views. The Commission terminates 60 days after submitting the final report. The final report is submitted under subsection (b). A Commission may use the 60-day period for concluding its activities, including providing testimony to Congress and disseminating the final report. The NTSB is responsible for investigating incidents described in section 3(a) and will transfer this responsibility to a Commission established by the Act after its initial meeting. Funding necessary for the Act is authorized to be appropriated and will remain available until the Commission's termination.
